posts.name: August Schroeder
posts.cooked: Are there any ideas or threads out there for converting a 3/4 inch dead axle to Rev hardware’s absolute encoder with a 1/2 inch hex bore?

posts.name: Connor
posts.cooked: That sounds like an interesting challenge

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if there are already existing threads, but I think the most obvious solution is just to run a gear off of your moving surface (since you’re on a dead axle) meshing with a gear on the absolute encoder, and then compensating for the gear ratio difference in code.

Use herringbone gears for less backlash and constrain the encoder to have an adjustable mesh with the gear on whatever’s moving on the dead axle.

edit: 3D-printed herringbone gears, there are a million free generators out there

posts.name: August Schroeder
posts.cooked: The only problem I can see with this is the fact that our dead axle is circular.

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked: That shouldn’t be an issue if I’m understanding what you’re describing correctly. You should face-mount the gear to the side of whatever’s pivoting, with a big hole in the middle to let the dead axle pass through.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I am assuming you want an absolute encoder on maxspline that has a dead axle through it… If not please elaborate and/or provide a sketch.

if looking for a maxspline throughbore I would either use one of Eliot’s encoder housings, or see if you can do a gt3 belt over to a jackshaft and measure it indirectly

link_counts.title: MAXSpline Through bore encoder - HELIUM Canandmag addon

posts.cooked: You just need to connect your adapter ( @banjogates is suggesting a 3D-printed gear) to the dead axle. You can do this with glue, or with set screws, or by drilling a hole through the tube and putting a pin or screw through it.
